content: Responding to critics of the interrogation tactics, Cheney said the United States did obtain useful information. "It is a fact that only detainees of the highest intelligence value were ever subjected to enhanced interrogation. You've heard endlessly about waterboarding. It happened to three terrorists," Cheney told an audience at the conservative American Enterprise Institute. The former vice president bristled over the complaints about interrogation from lawmakers, pointing out that leading members of Congress, including House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., were briefed on the programs and methods. "Yet for all these exacting efforts to do a hard and necessary job and to do it right, we hear from some quarters nothing but feigned outrage based on a false narrative," Cheney said. "In my long experience in Washington, few matters have inspired so much contrived indignation and phony moralizing as the interrogation methods applied to a few captured terrorists." that ain't no joke. "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

A republican with a political FUTURE should be coming forth in rebuttal. Not this old has-been with a controversial political past -- who spouts nothing but the neo-conservative ideology that the US people voted out of office last year. Today's republicans should urge Cheney to step down. It is time for this retired circus horse to be shown his pasture. I needed a good laugh and you provided it! Carter, Clinton, and Gore would probably agree! It is my opinion that former presidents and vice presidents should simply retire and stay out of the spotlight. Whatever the political affiliation, it is in bad taste to continue to TRY to set US policy after leaving office. A good example of how it should be done? George W. Bush. I respect his sense of discretion as he enjoys his retirement. This is the time for the republican party to find their new voice -- something centrist-- in preparation for the mid-terms in 2010. A re-hash of what was voted OUT in 2008 is not the answer, and that means Cheney is misplaced as the de-facto "spokeman." As an independent, I am not averse to voting republican if a new voice and agenda is forwarded -- and not with negatives, but with positives, and with a "we can do better, and this is how" attitude. Cheney fails to do that, and IMO is harming his party's chances for success.

content: I Don't pay too much attention to one or the other but President Obama was talking when I left to take the son to work across town and he was still going after it after I returned. content: quote: Originally posted by Kegler300: quote: Originally posted by 1WW: Did Cheney not receive the memo that he is no longer the vice-president? A republican with a political FUTURE should be coming forth in rebuttal. Not this old has-been with a controversial political past -- who spouts nothing but the neo-conservative ideology that the US people voted out of office last year. Today's republicans should urge Cheney to step down. It is time for this retired circus horse to be shown his pasture. I needed a good laugh and you provided it! Carter, Clinton, and Gore would probably agree! It is my opinion that former presidents and vice presidents should simply retire and stay out of the spotlight. Whatever the political affiliation, it is in bad taste to continue to TRY to set US policy after leaving office. A good example of how it should be done? George W. Bush. I respect his sense of discretion as he enjoys his retirement. This is the time for the republican party to find their new voice -- something centrist-- in preparation for the mid-terms in 2010. A re-hash of what was voted OUT in 2008 is not the answer, and that means Cheney is misplaced as the de-facto "spokeman." As an independent, I am not averse to voting republican if a new voice and agenda is forwarded -- and not with negatives, but with positives, and with a "we can do better, and this is how" attitude. Cheney fails to do that, and IMO is harming his party's chances for success.

content: Responding to critics of the interrogation tactics, Cheney said the United States did obtain useful information. "It is a fact that only detainees of the highest intelligence value were ever subjected to enhanced interrogation. You've heard endlessly about waterboarding. It happened to three terrorists," Cheney told an audience at the conservative American Enterprise Institute. The former vice president bristled over the complaints about interrogation from lawmakers, pointing out that leading members of Congress, including House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., were briefed on the programs and methods. "Yet for all these exacting efforts to do a hard and necessary job and to do it right, we hear from some quarters nothing but feigned outrage based on a false narrative," Cheney said. "In my long experience in Washington, few matters have inspired so much contrived indignation and phony moralizing as the interrogation methods applied to a few captured terrorists." that ain't no joke. "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

content: quote: Originally posted by Kegler300: quote: Originally posted by 1WW: Did Cheney not receive the memo that he is no longer the vice-president? A republican with a political FUTURE should be coming forth in rebuttal. Not this old has-been with a controversial political past -- who spouts nothing but the neo-conservative ideology that the US people voted out of office last year. Today's republicans should urge Cheney to step down. It is time for this retired circus horse to be shown his pasture. I needed a good laugh and you provided it! Carter, Clinton, and Gore would probably agree! It is my opinion that former presidents and vice presidents should simply retire and stay out of the spotlight. Whatever the political affiliation, it is in bad taste to continue to TRY to set US policy after leaving office. A good example of how it should be done? George W. Bush. I respect his sense of discretion as he enjoys his retirement. This is the time for the republican party to find their new voice -- something centrist-- in preparation for the mid-terms in 2010. A re-hash of what was voted OUT in 2008 is not the answer, and that means Cheney is misplaced as the de-facto "spokeman." As an independent, I am not averse to voting republican if a new voice and agenda is forwarded -- and not with negatives, but with positives, and with a "we can do better, and this is how" attitude. Cheney fails to do that, and IMO is harming his party's chances for success.

content: Responding to critics of the interrogation tactics, Cheney said the United States did obtain useful information. "It is a fact that only detainees of the highest intelligence value were ever subjected to enhanced interrogation. You've heard endlessly about waterboarding. It happened to three terrorists," Cheney told an audience at the conservative American Enterprise Institute. The former vice president bristled over the complaints about interrogation from lawmakers, pointing out that leading members of Congress, including House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., were briefed on the programs and methods. "Yet for all these exacting efforts to do a hard and necessary job and to do it right, we hear from some quarters nothing but feigned outrage based on a false narrative," Cheney said. "In my long experience in Washington, few matters have inspired so much contrived indignation and phony moralizing as the interrogation methods applied to a few captured terrorists." that ain't no joke. "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

That's wrong to begin with but don't make it a federal offense if the other guy defends himself. President Clinton never received harsh measures after leaving office, which he was wide open to get, from the new Bush administration. Many in the talk shows or news media perhaps, but for an official of or the President himself blaming the previous office holder shows weakness on his own part.
